Headline: A Tale Told Once Too Often
Abstract: On DVD it's fine to tell behind-the-scenes stories, even bland ones, but not the same story twice. One example is a special edition of Disney's "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea."
Lead_Paragraph: On DVD it's fine to tell behind-the-scenes stories, even bland ones, but not the same story twice. For example, in a director's commentary on a generally very fine special edition of "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea," released this week by Disney, the director Richard Fleischer talks about the relationship between his father, the animator Max Fleischer, and Walt Disney.
Snippet: On DVD it's fine to tell behind-the-scenes stories, even bland ones, but not the same story twice. One example is a special edition of Disney's "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea."
Author: Peter

Headline: 'Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'
Abstract: font size="-1" (May 23, 1984) Watching "Indiana Jones" is like spending a day at an amusement park, which is probably what Steven Spielberg and his associates intended.
Lead_Paragraph: IF you've ever been a child or, barring that, if you've ever been around children, ages 7 to about 11, you may remember the sort of game in which each child attempts to come up with the vilest, most disgusting, most repulsive, most stomach-turning meal he can think of. It might consist of sheeps' eyes in runny aspic, live cockroaches wrapped in spider webs, juicy worms a la king and bats' brains with anchovies and chocolate sauce.
Snippet: font size="-1" (May 23, 1984) Watching "Indiana Jones" is like spending a day at an amusement park, which is probably what Steven Spielberg and his associates intended.
Author: Vincent Canby

Headline: Zooming In on Real Life
Abstract: The Oscar-winning documentary "Murder on a Sunday Morning," an account of a murder trial in Florida, persistently stays in the faces of those involved in the case.
Lead_Paragraph: Watching Jean-Xavier de Lestrade's documentary "Murder on a Sunday Morning," you wonder how he got access to shoot as freely as he did. An account of a murder trial in Jacksonville, Fla., the film persistently stays in the faces of the 15-year-old defendant, Brenton Butler (who was acquitted), and his family; the dogged defense team; the prosecutor; and detectives assigned to the case.
Snippet: The Oscar-winning documentary "Murder on a Sunday Morning," an account of a murder trial in Florida, persistently stays in the faces of those involved in the case.
Author: Peter

Headline: 'Perdition,' With Its Ghosts
Abstract: A fine DVD released this week shows the real strengths of "Road to Perdition" are in the film's art direction, cinematography, sound, sound editing and original score.
Lead_Paragraph: Among the early front-runners for major Oscar nominations, Sam Mendes's "Road to Perdition" was passed in the home stretch by the likes of "The Pianist" and "Gangs of New York." In 1999 Mr. Mendes's first feature film, "American Beauty," won in the best film, director and actor categories, but this time the only "Perdition" contender for the so-called big six Oscars is Paul Newman as best supporting actor for his portayal of the mob boss John Rooney.
Snippet: A fine DVD released this week shows the real strengths of "Road to Perdition" are in the film's art direction, cinematography, sound, sound editing and original score.
Author: Peter

Headline: DVD Is Gaining Fast on Video
Abstract: One indicator of how fast the upstart DVD is catching the elderly videocassette is the number of discs and cassettes manufactured each year.

When it was shown as the opening-night selection of this year's New York Film Festival, Stephen Holden wrote: "Instead of flash, what Mr. Nicholson brings to his role is a sorrowful awareness of human complexity whose emotional depth matches anything he has done in the movies before." Headline: Old 'Dog,' New Tricks
Abstract: For a while in the 90's Quentin Tarantino swarmed all over the movies, and this month so it will be on DVD.
Lead_Paragraph: For a while in the 90's Quentin Tarantino swarmed all over the movies, and this month so it will be on DVD. On Tuesday the best of his films, "Pulp Fiction," and definitely not the best, "Jackie Brown," are to be released in special editions by Miramax. And on Aug. 27 a 10th-anniversary DVD of "Reservoir Dogs," his first film, is to be issued by Artisan.
Snippet: For a while in the 90's Quentin Tarantino swarmed all over the movies, and this month so it will be on DVD.

Headline: Making Room for DVD and VHS
Abstract: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies
Lead_Paragraph: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies. In short, there isn't money or shelf space for everything. More obscure titles that were once distributed routinely, if not profusely, on videocassette are being dropped by studios more interested in developing the biggest and best known older films in DVD special editions that will sell by the bushel at mass outlets like Best Buy and Wal- Mart.
Snippet: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies
Author: Peter

Headline: Imagining the Holocaust to Remember It
Abstract: font size="-1" (December 15, 1993) "Schindler's List," directed with fury and immediacy by a profoundly surprising Steven Spielberg, presents the Holocaust as if discovering it anew.
Lead_Paragraph: There is a real photographic record of some of the people and places depicted in "Schindler's List," and it has a haunting history. Raimund Titsch, an Austrian Catholic who managed a uniform factory within the Plaszow labor camp in Poland, surreptitiously took pictures of what he saw. Fearful of having the pictures developed, he hid his film in a steel box, which he buried in a park outside Vienna and then did not disturb for nearly 20 years. Although it was sold secretly by Titsch when he was terminally ill, the film remained undeveloped until after his death.
Snippet: font size="-1" (December 15, 1993) "Schindler's List," directed with fury and immediacy by a profoundly surprising Steven Spielberg, presents the Holocaust as if discovering it anew.
Author: Janet Malin

Headline: A Spiritual Trek for Salt in Tibet
Abstract: On July 23, Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary "The Saltmen of Tibet" on cassette and DVD.
Lead_Paragraph: Nothing beats a good trek movie. On Tuesday Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary "The Saltmen of Tibet" on cassette and DVD. At the outset a song tells us that we are in the Kingdom of Ling, at the center of the world, a blue-turquoise place. Nomads are preparing to drive 160 yaks on a monthlong pilgrimage to Lake Tsentso to collect salt to trade for grain.
Snippet: On July 23, Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary "The Saltmen of Tibet" on cassette and DVD.
Author: Peter

Headline: Marlon Brando, Oscar-Winning Actor, Is Dead at 80
Abstract: The rebellious prodigy, who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting, died in Los Angeles.
Lead_Paragraph: Marlon Brando, the rebellious prodigy who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting but whose obstinacy and eccentricity prevented him from fully realizing the promise of his early genius, died on Thursday at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 80.
Snippet: The rebellious prodigy, who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting, died in Los Angeles.
Author: Rick Lyman

Headline: In Cannes, This Festival of Film Lives Up to Its Purpose
Abstract: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Lead_Paragraph: CANNES, France, May 13 — People who have never been to the Cannes Film Festival like to imagine that it is a nonstop, two-week orgy of cinema and celebrity, awash in Champagne and movie-star glamour, illuminated by a million paparazzi flashbulbs. People who have been there, on the other hand, like to pretend that it isn't. In recent years, especially, some of us have returned home with a litany of complaints. The films are disappointing. The pace is grueling. The security guards are unfriendly. The schedules are hard to read. It sometimes rains. Boo-hoo.
Snippet: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Author: A. Scott

Headline: George Lucas: A Galaxy of Myth, Money and Kids
Abstract: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Lead_Paragraph: SAN RAFAEL , Calif. — LIKE his films, which have brought vivid and elaborate fantasies to life in the multiplexes of America's most mundane shopping malls, George Lucas's elaborate film-set-like home is sequestered in a surprisingly everyday neighborhood here. Turn right by a supermarket parking lot, head up a hill past an assortment of lusterless middle-class homes -- an old washer and dryer are abandoned in the driveway of one -- and a visitor arrives at the electronically controlled gate that admits one to this private world. Inside, a huge 1860's Victorian house, remodeled and filled with the latest electronic gadgetry, perfectly expresses Mr. Lucas's retro-futurism.
Snippet: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Author: Orville Schell

Headline: 'Empire of the Sun'
Abstract: font size="-1" (December 9, 1987) Steven Spielberg's film about a privileged British schoolboy living in Shanghai in 1941 seems to speak a language all its own.
Lead_Paragraph: GOD playing tennis: that's what Jim Graham (Christian Bale), a privileged British schoolboy living in high colonial style in the pre-Pearl Harbor Shanghai of 1941, sees in one of his dreams. God taking a photograph: Jim thinks he sees that four years and seemingly several lifetimes later, as a starving, exhausted prisoner witnessing the brilliant light of the atomic bomb.
Snippet: font size="-1" (December 9, 1987) Steven Spielberg's film about a privileged British schoolboy living in Shanghai in 1941 seems to speak a language all its own.
Author: Janet Maslin

Headline: Secrecy Shrouds a 'Star Wars' Sequel
Abstract: CRESCENT CITY, Calif. — All the locals in this tiny (population 2,500) timber and fishing community know is that for some reason, a surprising number of strangers have moved into their midst, filling some of the motels and restaurants that would otherwise be empty in the worst recession since World War II. But until now, the inhabitants of this northernmost California town, where the official unemployment rate has topped 28 percent, have had no inkling of who the strangers are or why they are there. They have not known that practically in their own backyard, a $32.5 million film has been in production and that roughly $2 million of this amount is being spent right here on location, much of it on local salaries, food, lodging, transportation and materials.

Headline: 'E.T. the Extra-Terrestial'
Abstract: font size="-1" (June 11, 1982) "E.T. the Extra-Terrestial" may become a children's classic of the space age.
Lead_Paragraph: THE camera pans across a starry sky so clear that it has the effect of putting you in touch with the galaxies. When you lie on your back and stare into such a night sky, you feel as if you were tumbling upward through space. The camera slowly descends to earth to come to rest on a spaceship, its lights ablaze, comfortably settled in a clearing in a California forest. Small, Munchkin-sized creatures, whose abdomens glow on and off like those of fireflies, attend to their tasks of gathering specimens of earth rocks and plant life.
Snippet: font size="-1" (June 11, 1982) "E.T. the Extra-Terrestial" may become a children's classic of the space age.
Author: Vincent Canby

Headline: It Fakes a Village: Lars von Triers America
Abstract: "Dogville," Lars von Triers ruthlessly deconstructed take on small-town life, is a fantasy of America no American would ever dream up.
Lead_Paragraph: DOGVILLE, the setting for Lars von Trier's new film of the same name, is a tiny, obscure town in the Colorado Rockies. The adult population numbers about 15, and during the Great Depression, when the film takes place, these people's lives are busy, joyless and harsh. The hard-bitten folk who inhabited the Northwestern factory town in "Dancer in the Dark," Mr. von Trier's previous foray into Americana, at least had a community theater, but the most Dogville can offer is some meetings presided over by a self-styled intellectual named Tom Edison Jr. (the English actor Paul Bettany).
Snippet: "Dogville," Lars von Triers ruthlessly deconstructed take on small-town life, is a fantasy of America no American would ever dream up.
Author: A. Scott

Headline: Two Ways to See How It's Done
Abstract: Can DVD's teach filmmaking? For a how-to on the blockbuster, we have Michael Bay's "Pearl Harbor." If smaller explosive productions are of interest, try the Andy Sidaris Film School.

Abstract: KAATERSKILL FALLS
Lead_Paragraph: KAATERSKILL FALLS "Knife in the Water" moves to the Catskills. In this low-budget, Americanized version of Roman Polanski's 1962 thriller, a Manhattan couple heading out on a country weekend pick up a young hitchhiker who ends up spending the night with them. The three are soon faced with a harrowing moral quandary. Josh Apter and Peter Olsen directed. June 5.

Headline: Oscar Tsunami? Nope, a Wavelet
Abstract: Oscar nominations, announced on Feb. 12, don't offer video dealers much new to trumpet.
Lead_Paragraph: Oscar nominations, announced on Feb. 12, don't offer video dealers much new to trumpet. "Moulin Rouge" has been around on videocassette and DVD since December, and none of the other best-picture nominees are coming anytime soon. Only "Gosford Park" has a release date scheduled: May 28. "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring," the candidate with the clumsiest title and most nominations (13), "A Beautiful Mind" and "In the Bedroom" should be along in the summer or fall.
Snippet: Oscar nominations, announced on Feb. 12, don't offer video dealers much new to trumpet.
Author: Peter

Headline: New Views on Classics
Abstract: New Views On Classics.
Lead_Paragraph: Aflock of old films is going into the release mix this week and next. With nearly an hour added to the 1979 original, Francis Ford Coppola's "Apocalypse Now Redux," issued on Tuesday by Paramount, becomes "richer, stranger and more coherent," A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times . Next Tuesday Kino will release "The Blue Angel" (1930) in both the English and German versions on DVD. For sheer aplomb, nothing beats Marlene Dietrich's screen test, one of a half-dozen extra features.
Snippet: New Views On Classics.

Headline: 'The Color Purple'
Abstract: font size="-1" (June 11, 1982) Steven Spielberg has fashioning a grand, multi-hanky entertainment that is as pretty and lavish as the Alice Walker novel on which it is based is plain.
Lead_Paragraph: SWEETNESS and stridency exist side by side in Alice Walker's ''Color Purple,'' a book whose great virtue is the conversational immediacy that lets its characters spring to life on the page. In Steven Spielberg's film version, which opens today at the Beekman and other theaters, the characters are also big and vibrant, but beyond that they resemble Miss Walker's barely at all. Mr. Spielberg has looked on the sunny side of Miss Walker's novel, fashioning a grand, multi-hanky entertainment that is as pretty and lavish as the book is plain. If the book is set in the harsh, impoverished atmosphere of rural Georgia, the movie unfolds in a cozy, comfortable, flower-filled wonderland.
Snippet: font size="-1" (June 11, 1982) Steven Spielberg has fashioning a grand, multi-hanky entertainment that is as pretty and lavish as the Alice Walker novel on which it is based is plain.
Author: Janet Maslin

Headline: Marlon Brando, Oscar-Winning Actor, Is Dead at 80
Abstract: The rebellious prodigy, who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting, died in Los Angeles.
Lead_Paragraph: Marlon Brando, the rebellious prodigy who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting but whose obstinacy and eccentricity prevented him from fully realizing the promise of his early genius, died on Thursday at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 80.
Snippet: The rebellious prodigy, who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting, died in Los Angeles.

Headline: In Cannes, This Festival of Film Lives Up to Its Purpose
Abstract: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Lead_Paragraph: CANNES, France, May 13 — People who have never been to the Cannes Film Festival like to imagine that it is a nonstop, two-week orgy of cinema and celebrity, awash in Champagne and movie-star glamour, illuminated by a million paparazzi flashbulbs. People who have been there, on the other hand, like to pretend that it isn't. In recent years, especially, some of us have returned home with a litany of complaints. The films are disappointing. The pace is grueling. The security guards are unfriendly. The schedules are hard to read. It sometimes rains. Boo-hoo.
Snippet: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Author: A. Scott

Headline: It Fakes a Village: Lars von Triers America
Abstract: "Dogville," Lars von Triers ruthlessly deconstructed take on small-town life, is a fantasy of America no American would ever dream up.
Lead_Paragraph: DOGVILLE, the setting for Lars von Trier's new film of the same name, is a tiny, obscure town in the Colorado Rockies. The adult population numbers about 15, and during the Great Depression, when the film takes place, these people's lives are busy, joyless and harsh. The hard-bitten folk who inhabited the Northwestern factory town in "Dancer in the Dark," Mr. von Trier's previous foray into Americana, at least had a community theater, but the most Dogville can offer is some meetings presided over by a self-styled intellectual named Tom Edison Jr. (the English actor Paul Bettany).
Snippet: "Dogville," Lars von Triers ruthlessly deconstructed take on small-town life, is a fantasy of America no American would ever dream up.
Author: A. Scott

Headline: Zooming In on Real Life
Abstract: The Oscar-winning documentary "Murder on a Sunday Morning," an account of a murder trial in Florida, persistently stays in the faces of those involved in the case.
Lead_Paragraph: Watching Jean-Xavier de Lestrade's documentary "Murder on a Sunday Morning," you wonder how he got access to shoot as freely as he did. An account of a murder trial in Jacksonville, Fla., the film persistently stays in the faces of the 15-year-old defendant, Brenton Butler (who was acquitted), and his family; the dogged defense team; the prosecutor; and detectives assigned to the case.

Headline: Ready to Play a Mind Game?
Abstract: Don't bother poking the menu key on a new DVD edition of Christopher Nolan's "Memento." Neither of the two discs has a menu, or one that lists features in standard fashion.
Lead_Paragraph: Don't bother poking the menu key on a new DVD edition of Christopher Nolan's "Memento," released this week by Columbia TriStar. Neither of the two discs has a menu, or one that lists features in standard fashion. Instead, one gets to the contents through a "mental health battery," or series of questions and exercises to measure contextual retention, comprehension skills and the like. Respond the right way, and you will find the feature you seek. Answer another way, and you won't.

Headline: DVD Is Gaining Fast on Video

Lead_Paragraph: One indicator of how fast the upstart DVD is catching the elderly videocassette is the number of discs and cassettes manufactured each year. Headline: In Little Time, Pop Culture Is Almost Back to Normal
Abstract: As the country moves past its initial period of shock over last month's terrorist attacks, what's most striking is how unchanged the appetite for popular culture seems to be.
Lead_Paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 — As the country moves past its initial period of shock over last month's terrorist attacks, and movie releases and the opening of the television seasons return to their normal rhythm, what's most striking is how unchanged the appetite for popular culture seems to be.
Snippet: As the country moves past its initial period of shock over last month's terrorist attacks, what's most striking is how unchanged the appetite for popular culture seems to be.
Author: Rick With

Headline: 'Cleopatra' on DVD: Extravagant, Except in Quality
Abstract: A new three-disc DVD special edition of the 1963 film "Cleopatra" makes it clear that the major spectacle took place behind the scenes
Lead_Paragraph: CLEOPATRA." More than two years in the making. A cast of thousands. Starring Elizabeth Taylor, Rex Harrison and Richard Burton. "Not a terrible film by any means," said Martin Landau, who played the Roman officer Rufio in the movie, directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. It was pretty bad, though, despite its front-rank talent. When it opened in the summer of 1963, the film was as notorious for its extravagant production costs as for the tumultuous affair between Burton and Ms. Taylor that had begun on the set. On screen, the machinations in Roman and Egyptian high places had their moments, but artistically "Cleopatra" was swallowed by its gilded pavilions. For all the gigantism, one critic called it a mouse.
Snippet: A new three-disc DVD special edition of the 1963 film "Cleopatra" makes it clear that the major spectacle took place behind the scenes
Author: Peter

Headline: An Olympics Ever So Human
Abstract: "Tokyo Olympiad," Kon Ichikawa's 170-minutes documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, is one of the most enthralling films about sport ever made.
Lead_Paragraph: When Kon Ichikawa was asked to make a documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, the Japanese authorities from the emperor on down expected his cameras to stick to business on the track or in the pool and not go wandering off at every little distraction. Yet no sooner does Billy Mills of the United States win the 10,000-meter run than Mr. Ichikawa moves off into the crowd for a close look at the wattles of 60-something men.

Headline: Unconventional Perspectives on American History and the Irish Troubles
Abstract: Reviews of Park Chanwook's "Lady Vengeance," Lars von Trier's "Manderlay," Neil Jordan's "Breakfast on Pluto," a program of avant-garde short films and more.
Lead_Paragraph: Both Neil Jordan's "Breakfast on Pluto," the centerpiece of the New York Film Festival, and Lars von Trier's "Manderlay" stretch the traditional boundaries of what we think of as epic films. The hero/heroine of Mr. Jordan's sprawling comedy is a male transvestite; the heroine of "Manderlay," the second part of Mr. von Trier's United States trilogy, is a gangster's idealistic daughter whose grand do-gooder schemes inevitably backfire. The movies are political in opposite ways. Mr. Jordan's radically apolitical protagonist, Kitten, mirrors the absurdity of war (the Irish troubles). "Manderlay" is an allegorical tract about racism in America that asks uncomfortable questions about slavery and its legacy that no major American filmmaker would dare address so boldly. Both are important films. STEPHEN HOLDEN
Snippet: Reviews of Park Chanwook's "Lady Vengeance," Lars von Trier's "Manderlay," Neil Jordan's "Breakfast on Pluto," a program of avant-garde short films and more.

Headline: Rick or Victor? A Fateful Choice
Abstract: In his commentary on a new DVD edition of "Casablanca" (1942), the critic Roger Ebert tells about watching the movie one shot at a time.
Lead_Paragraph: The critic Roger Ebert has long examined certain movies frame by frame in the company of filmmakers. When he began, the films were 16 millimeter. "Now we use DVD," he said this week by telephone from Chicago. "Just go into a room with the lights off. Freeze a frame. You can back up." In his commentary on a new DVD edition of "Casablanca" (1942), released on Tuesday by Warner, he tells about watching the movie one shot at a time with the cinematographer Haskell Wexler.

Headline: Dogme: Still Strong, but Less Dogmatic
Abstract: It has now been nine years since the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier gave birth to Dogme95, and the movement he began is still going strong.
Lead_Paragraph: ON March 20, 1995, the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier stood up at a conference in Paris on the 100th anniversary of the cinema and tossed handfuls of bright red pamphlets into the audience. "It seems to me that for the last 10 years film has been rubbish," Mr. von Trier proclaimed. "So my question was, what can we do about this?" His answer was Dogme95, a new film movement, born half in facetiousness and half in seriousness, whose rules were spelled out in the flyers as "The Vow of Chastity."
Snippet: It has now been nine years since the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier gave birth to Dogme95, and the movement he began is still going strong.

Headline: George Lucas: A Galaxy of Myth, Money and Kids
Abstract: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Lead_Paragraph: SAN RAFAEL , Calif. — LIKE his films, which have brought vivid and elaborate fantasies to life in the multiplexes of America's most mundane shopping malls, George Lucas's elaborate film-set-like home is sequestered in a surprisingly everyday neighborhood here. Turn right by a supermarket parking lot, head up a hill past an assortment of lusterless middle-class homes -- an old washer and dryer are abandoned in the driveway of one -- and a visitor arrives at the electronically controlled gate that admits one to this private world. Inside, a huge 1860's Victorian house, remodeled and filled with the latest electronic gadgetry, perfectly expresses Mr. Lucas's retro-futurism.
Snippet: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Author: Orville Schell

Headline: In Cannes, This Festival of Film Lives Up to Its Purpose
Abstract: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Lead_Paragraph: CANNES, France, May 13 — People who have never been to the Cannes Film Festival like to imagine that it is a nonstop, two-week orgy of cinema and celebrity, awash in Champagne and movie-star glamour, illuminated by a million paparazzi flashbulbs. People who have been there, on the other hand, like to pretend that it isn't. In recent years, especially, some of us have returned home with a litany of complaints. The films are disappointing. The pace is grueling. The security guards are unfriendly. The schedules are hard to read. It sometimes rains. Boo-hoo.
Snippet: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Author: A. Scott

Headline: Disney and DVD Hit a Milestone
Abstract: It was the "last of the red-hot fairy tales," says Don Hahn on a new DVD of "Beauty and the Beast," to be released Tuesday by Disney.
Lead_Paragraph: It was the "last of the red-hot fairy tales," says Don Hahn on a new DVD of "Beauty and the Beast," to be released Tuesday by Disney. Mr. Hahn, the film's producer, then ticks off three predecessors: "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," "Cinderella" and "Sleeping Beauty." By 1959 Disney had bagged all three for animated features, but for various reasons the studio had held off on "Beast." The right opportunity didn't jell until the late 80's, about the time of "The Little Mermaid" (1989), the first of the studio's new wave of animated films that appealed to older audiences as well as children.
Snippet: It was the "last of the red-hot fairy tales," says Don Hahn on a new DVD of "Beauty and the Beast," to be released Tuesday by Disney.
Author: Peter

Lead_Paragraph: Oscar nominations, announced on Feb. 12, don't offer video dealers much new to trumpet. "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring," the candidate with the clumsiest title and most nominations (13), "A Beautiful Mind" and "In the Bedroom" should be along in the summer or fall.

Headline: New Views on Classics

Scott wrote in The New York Times . Next Tuesday Kino will release "The Blue Angel" (1930) in both the English and German versions on DVD. Not a "Titanic"-size rush perhaps, but definitely a video event on the order of, say, one of the big Disney releases back in the days when consumers soaked up animated features by the tens of millions of cassettes.

Headline: Marlon Brando, Oscar-Winning Actor, Is Dead at 80
Abstract: The rebellious prodigy, who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting, died in Los Angeles.
Lead_Paragraph: Marlon Brando, the rebellious prodigy who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting but whose obstinacy and eccentricity prevented him from fully realizing the promise of his early genius, died on Thursday at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 80.
Snippet: The rebellious prodigy, who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting, died in Los Angeles.
Author: Rick Lyman

Headline: In Cannes, This Festival of Film Lives Up to Its Purpose
Abstract: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Lead_Paragraph: CANNES, France, May 13 — People who have never been to the Cannes Film Festival like to imagine that it is a nonstop, two-week orgy of cinema and celebrity, awash in Champagne and movie-star glamour, illuminated by a million paparazzi flashbulbs. People who have been there, on the other hand, like to pretend that it isn't. In recent years, especially, some of us have returned home with a litany of complaints. The films are disappointing. The pace is grueling. The security guards are unfriendly. The schedules are hard to read. It sometimes rains. Boo-hoo.
Snippet: The 57th Cannes festival has, in its first few days, shown signs of fulfilling the fantasy of what it could and should be.
Author: A. Scott

Headline: Experiences of a New Director
Abstract: With its room for interviews and other opportunities for documentation, DVD can be especially good at catching fresh filmmaking experiences, particularly by first-time directors.
Lead_Paragraph: With its room for interviews and other opportunities for documentation, DVD can be especially good at catching fresh filmmaking experiences, particularly by first-time directors. "Never let them see you sweat," John Singleton says on a two-disc special edition of "Boyz N the Hood" (1991) released this week by Columbia TriStar. He was four months out of film school at the University of Southern California, and Columbia Pictures had given him $6 million to make a movie shot in the ghetto. Every day he showed up early to learn what everybody was doing.
Snippet: With its room for interviews and other opportunities for documentation, DVD can be especially good at catching fresh filmmaking experiences, particularly by first-time directors.
Author: Peter

Last August "The Fellowship of the Ring," the first of Peter Jackson's three films, was released on DVD with a fair-size list of extras. Headline: Rick or Victor? A Fateful Choice
Abstract: In his commentary on a new DVD edition of "Casablanca" (1942), the critic Roger Ebert tells about watching the movie one shot at a time.
Lead_Paragraph: The critic Roger Ebert has long examined certain movies frame by frame in the company of filmmakers. When he began, the films were 16 millimeter. "Now we use DVD," he said this week by telephone from Chicago. "Just go into a room with the lights off. Freeze a frame. You can back up." In his commentary on a new DVD edition of "Casablanca" (1942), released on Tuesday by Warner, he tells about watching the movie one shot at a time with the cinematographer Haskell Wexler.

Headline: Video Revenue Is Still Rising
Abstract: While 2003 movie box office receipts are down by more than 4 percent from last year, video revenue is up by 16 percent.
Lead_Paragraph: The factors that restrict the economy don't have too tight a grip on home video. While 2003 movie box-office receipts are down by more than 4 percent from last year, video revenue is up by 16 percent, according to a report by Video Business magazine. In the first half of the year consumers spent $10.2 billion buying and renting DVD's and videocassettes, a healthy performance for an industry that some analysts once wrote off as road kill on the supposed fast lane to the information superhighway.
Snippet: While 2003 movie box office receipts are down by more than 4 percent from last year, video revenue is up by 16 percent.
Author: Peter

Abstract: Remastered versions of four Charlie Chaplin classics, "The Gold Rush," "Modern Times," "The Great Dictator" and "Limelight," have been released on DVD by Warner Home Video.
Lead_Paragraph: In the beginning (of DVD), some of Charlie Chaplin's feature films were released by Image Entertainment . Those DVD's were made from masters used for laser discs. "They were top of the line in 1992, but what was good on laser disc doesn't translate well onto DVD," said George Feltenstein, senior vice president for classic catalogs of Warner Home Video.

Headline: A Tale Explained as Well as Told
Abstract: Extra features are at battalion strength on a three-disc DVD special edition of Ridley Scott's "Black Hawk Down."
Lead_Paragraph: Like a wave of the title helicopters, "Black Hawk Down" has landed this week in a three-disc DVD special edition ($39.95) from Columbia TriStar. Extra features are at battalion strength for Ridley Scott's film about the ambush of American troops in Mogadishu, Somalia, in October 1993. Mr. Scott and many others contribute to three separate audio commentaries. A documentary about the making of the film runs 150 minutes, seven minutes longer than the movie. Two documentaries, from the History Channel and the PBS "Frontline" series, examine the real battle of Mogadishu.
Snippet: Extra features are at battalion strength on a three-disc DVD special edition of Ridley Scott's "Black Hawk Down."
Author: Peter

The trilogy will make a four-disc set, with George Lucas, an executive producer of the films, Steven Spielberg, their director, and Harrison Ford, their star, adding comments to the extra features on the fourth disc.
Snippet: DVD sets, and news about them, have been the focus this week and last.

Chief critic of the paper, Hall was occasionally a reporter, too, and here he conveyed the electricity of a remarkable movie moment.

Headline: War's Impact? What Impact?
Abstract: The video industry doesn't crow about it, of course, but national crises normally don't hurt the bottom line or alter the flow of releases.
Lead_Paragraph: The video industry doesn't crow about it, of course, but national crises normally don't hurt the bottom line or alter the flow of releases. After Sept. 11 retailers found themselves heir to a cocooning effect, a general withdrawal to home and hearth with a pile of movies. Then it was supposed that tastes would tilt to comedy and light subjects, but violent action sounded no retreat.
Snippet: The video industry doesn't crow about it, of course, but national crises normally don't hurt the bottom line or alter the flow of releases.
Author: Peter

Headline: The Show Goes On, but Mood Is Subdued
Abstract: The mood of the Academy Awards was soured by the increasingly destructive conflict in Iraq and by pangs of conscience among film industry figures.
Lead_Paragraph: LOS ANGELES, March 23 — After wrestling for weeks with the prospect of war, Hollywood pressed ahead today with the Academy Awards — but barely.
Snippet: The mood of the Academy Awards was soured by the increasingly destructive conflict in Iraq and by pangs of conscience among film industry figures.
Author: Nick Madigan

Headline: The Movie About Movies
Abstract: On a DVD of François Truffaut's "Day for Night" (1973), the film scholar Annette Insdorf notes that there have been many movies about making movies before and since, but this is "the one."
Lead_Paragraph: Two of the week's better DVD's stand out as bellwethers of their kind. On a disc of François Truffaut's "Day for Night" (1973), from Warner, the film scholar Annette Insdorf notes that there have been many movies about making movies before and since, but this is "the one." In the sprawling landscape of television cop shows, there may be no "one," so to speak, but in 1993 the first season of "NYPD Blue," released on Tuesday by Fox, changed the genre forever.
Snippet: On a DVD of François Truffaut's "Day for Night" (1973), the film scholar Annette Insdorf notes that there have been many movies about making movies before and since, but this is "the one."
Author: Peter

Headline: 'Perdition,' With Its Ghosts
Abstract: A fine DVD released this week shows the real strengths of "Road to Perdition" are in the film's art direction, cinematography, sound, sound editing and original score.
Lead_Paragraph: Among the early front-runners for major Oscar nominations, Sam Mendes's "Road to Perdition" was passed in the home stretch by the likes of "The Pianist" and "Gangs of New York." In 1999 Mr. Mendes's first feature film, "American Beauty," won in the best film, director and actor categories, but this time the only "Perdition" contender for the so-called big six Oscars is Paul Newman as best supporting actor for his portayal of the mob boss John Rooney.
Snippet: A fine DVD released this week shows the real strengths of "Road to Perdition" are in the film's art direction, cinematography, sound, sound editing and original score.
Author: Peter

Headline: Hits' Quick Trip Into the Home
Abstract: Having rushed big summer movies onto DVD and VHS in time for the holidays, home video isn't letting up on the accelerator with major titles from theater runs in December.
Lead_Paragraph: Having rushed big summer movies onto DVD and VHS in time for the holidays, home video isn't letting up on the accelerator with major titles from theater runs in December. Last week Columbia TriStar set a release date of March 25 for "Maid in Manhattan," the Jennifer Lopez vehicle. This week Warner scheduled "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" for April 11.
Snippet: Having rushed big summer movies onto DVD and VHS in time for the holidays, home video isn't letting up on the accelerator with major titles from theater runs in December.

Headline: Selections From Mexico
Abstract: Desert Mountain Media, a distributor that focuses on niches far from Hollywood, is planning to release 80 titles from Latin America.
Lead_Paragraph: As general manager of the Sony DVD Center, Leslie Haas saw that mainline films were squeezing out other material on disc. So in the fall of 2001 she left and helped start Desert Mountain Media, a distributor in Phoenix that focuses on niches far from Hollywood.
Snippet: Desert Mountain Media, a distributor that focuses on niches far from Hollywood, is planning to release 80 titles from Latin America.

Headline: Making Crime a Mind Game
Abstract: Steven Spielberg hasn't rushed his films into DVD, but he's gradually becoming the life of the format, so to speak.
Lead_Paragraph: Steven Spielberg hasn't rushed his films into DVD, but he's gradually becoming the life of the format, so to speak. Staying away from the director's commentary, he has jumped in almost everywhere else during documentaries and other features on special editions of "Jaws," "Close Encounters of the Third Kind," " E.T. the Extraterrestrial" and "A.I." Now he does the same with "Minority Report," released this week on two discs by DreamWorks.
Snippet: Steven Spielberg hasn't rushed his films into DVD, but he's gradually becoming the life of the format, so to speak.
Author: Peter

Headline: After the Credits, the Elaboration
Abstract: Filmmakers are finding various ways to elaborate on their work on DVD.
Lead_Paragraph: Filmmakers are finding various ways to elaborate on their work on DVD. If standard director's commentaries don't appeal, question-and-answer sessions, often with college students, are an alternative. Or a director can retreat to a nook, so to speak, on a disc and discuss a particular aspect of the film.
Snippet: Filmmakers are finding various ways to elaborate on their work on DVD.
Author: Peter

Headline: Destined to Be Classics
Abstract: Two first feature films by major directors were released on DVD this week: Mel Brooks's "The Producers" (1968) and Ridley Scott's "The Duellists" (1977).
Lead_Paragraph: Two first feature films by major directors were released on DVD this week. Mel Brooks's recollections of "The Producers" (1968), from MGM, resemble Ridley Scott's of "The Duellists" (1977), released by Paramount, in one respect: both movies weren't exactly accorded roaring welcomes at the outset.
Snippet: Two first feature films by major directors were released on DVD this week: Mel Brooks's "The Producers" (1968) and Ridley Scott's "The Duellists" (1977).
Author: Peter

Headline: Old Films Meet New Technology
Abstract: Paramount took extra measures with its very fine-looking special editions of William Wyler's "Roman Holiday" (1953) and Billy Wilder's "Sunset Boulevard" (1950).
Lead_Paragraph: DVD can be unforgiving with older films. "It's such a lossless medium," said Phil Murphy, senior vice president for operations for Paramount television. By lossless he refers to visual glitches on much-used prints that are hard if not impossible to avoid on disc. On videotape there is a kind of settling into visual mediocrity that results in a loss of the bad along with the good, a kind of softening of imperfections. Only so much can be expected from VHS in the first place.
Snippet: Paramount took extra measures with its very fine-looking special editions of William Wyler's "Roman Holiday" (1953) and Billy Wilder's "Sunset Boulevard" (1950).
Author: Peter

Headline: Once More Around With 'The Rings'
Abstract: If there's such a thing as the perfect DVD movie, it has to be "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring."
Lead_Paragraph: If there's such a thing as the perfect DVD movie, it has to be "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring." On Tuesday New Line is to release two four-disc special editions only three months after issuing a basic two-disc DVD in August. This time Peter Jackson's film has been lengthened by 30 minutes in a "platinum edition" ($39.99) loaded with 30 hours of features and a "collector's DVD gift set" with even more extras and upgraded packaging ($79.92).
Snippet: If there's such a thing as the perfect DVD movie, it has to be "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring."
Author: Peter

Abstract: On this week's release schedule, "Y Tu Mamá También" sits unabashedly atop the very large video presences of James Bond and Steven Spielberg.

Headline: Big Shrieks, Bigger Profits
Abstract: Disney won't discuss its projections for "Monsters, Inc.," but with any big Disney title it's always fun to conjecture how it will stack up against the studio's other major titles.
Lead_Paragraph: e just try to entertain ourselves," said Pete Docter, the director of "Monsters, Inc.," to be released on Tuesday by Disney. He and other filmmakers at Pixar Animation Studios, which created the film, start with things they were sure of in childhood. For example, they knew that toys come to life when left by themselves with no humans around, as in the two "Toy Story" movies.

Headline: From Directors, a Word, or Two
Abstract: As the DVD audience broadens, so does appreciation of the disc's extra features.
Lead_Paragraph: As the DVD audience broadens, so does appreciation of the disc's extra features. Consumer studies by the DVD Entertainment Group, a trade association, rank improved picture and sound as DVD's most valued attributes. Extra scenes, outtakes and especially bloopers (always a favorite with fans) and behind-the-scenes looks at movies being made also score highly.
Snippet: As the DVD audience broadens, so does appreciation of the disc's extra features.
Author: Peter

Headline: 'In the Bedroom' Without Frills
Abstract: There isn't an extra feature to be found on the DVD release of Todd Field's "In the Bedroom."
Lead_Paragraph: With all the attention "In the Bedroom" had in theaters, not to mention its five Oscar nominations, its director, Todd Field, could be excused for some soul-baring in the form of a director's commentary or the like on the DVD, to be released Tuesday by Buena Vista. Instead there isn't an extra feature to be found — another smart move for a small, quiet film that tells its exceedingly powerful story in rich detail but totally without excess.
Snippet: There isn't an extra feature to be found on the DVD release of Todd Field's "In the Bedroom."
Author: Peter

Headline: Christmas Rush Is Ready to Roll
Abstract: Around home video it's already Christmas, or, more accurately, the season that starts in September and runs into January.
Lead_Paragraph: Around home video it's already Christmas, or, more accurately, the season that starts in September and runs into January. Since the time of "Batman" (1989), studio video divisions have hurried summer blockbusters into the holiday market. This year promises an epic pileup of big films in theaters now.

Headline: An Olympics Ever So Human
Abstract: "Tokyo Olympiad," Kon Ichikawa's 170-minutes documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, is one of the most enthralling films about sport ever made.
Lead_Paragraph: When Kon Ichikawa was asked to make a documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, the Japanese authorities from the emperor on down expected his cameras to stick to business on the track or in the pool and not go wandering off at every little distraction. Yet no sooner does Billy Mills of the United States win the 10,000-meter run than Mr. Ichikawa moves off into the crowd for a close look at the wattles of 60-something men.
Snippet: "Tokyo Olympiad," Kon Ichikawa's 170-minutes documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, is one of the most enthralling films about sport ever made.
Author: Peter

Headline: DVD Has Begun to Take Over
Abstract: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format.
Lead_Paragraph: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format. Last week Circuit City, the large electronics retailer, said it planned to drop videocassettes altogether in favor of the disc. Of the more than 10 million copies of "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" sold since its release by Warner on May 28, almost 60 percent were DVD's.
Snippet: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format.
Author: Peter

Headline: The Fine Points of a Murder
Abstract: With his "Gosford Park" due on Tuesday on VHS and DVD from Universal, Robert Altman sounded more ready than eager.
Lead_Paragraph: With his "Gosford Park" due on Tuesday on VHS and DVD from Universal, Robert Altman sounded more ready than eager. "A lot more people are going to see this work on video and DVD than in theaters, so I can't ignore it," he said this week. "So the whole idea is to make it fit your film better."
Snippet: With his "Gosford Park" due on Tuesday on VHS and DVD from Universal, Robert Altman sounded more ready than eager.
Author: Peter

Headline: It's Not a Wrap
Abstract: As DVD proliferates, its extra features are adding dimensions to moviemaking by allowing directors a second chance to sharpen and expand on their original films.
Lead_Paragraph: As DVD proliferates, some ardent boosters contend that its extra features are adding dimensions to moviemaking by allowing directors a second chance to sharpen and expand on their original films. The director Ron Howard doesn't go quite that far, however. "I love DVD's, watch them at home, but I don't scan a lot of the extras so I don't have a real sense of it as a medium per se," he said this week.
Snippet: As DVD proliferates, its extra features are adding dimensions to moviemaking by allowing directors a second chance to sharpen and expand on their original films.
Author: Peter

Headline: 'Lord of the Rings' Leads Oscar Nominations
Abstract: A three-hour epic about elves, dwarfs, wizards and small, hairy-footed hobbits dominated the 74th annual Academy Award nominations this morning, coming away with 13 of them.

Headline: Hollywood as Biographer
Abstract: Two television movies honored at the recent Golden Globe Awards feature winning performances from actors playing Hollywood legends.

In the television category, however, two winning performances are on cassette and DVD. One of them is interesting and worth a look. The other is truly memorable.

Headline: Choosing Bells or Whistles
Abstract: The average price of DVD players, expected to be in 25 million homes by the end of the year, is about $180, down from about $500 when the format was introduced in 1997.
Lead_Paragraph: ost things in the movie business are disappointments," said Ben Feingold, president of the Columbia TriStar Motion Picture Group. DVD isn't one of them. Industry figures show that the average price of DVD players, expected to be in 25 million homes by the end of the year, is about $180, down from about $500 when the format was introduced in 1997. No one can be sure of anything in the current economic climate, but retailers consider $200 a price for the people.
Snippet: The average price of DVD players, expected to be in 25 million homes by the end of the year, is about $180, down from about $500 when the format was introduced in 1997.

Headline: Super Tuesday of Big Hits
Abstract: Super Tuesday Of Big Hits.
Lead_Paragraph: DVD's Super Tuesday is Sept. 25. A digitally remastered "Citizen Kane" from Warner leads a half-dozen big releases, among them "The French Connection," William Friedkin's 1971 film that has largely set the standard for crime drama ever since. "The best action film of the modern era," said Bruce Goldstein, repertory director of Film Forum, which will show it from Sept. 28 through Oct. 4.
Snippet: Super Tuesday Of Big Hits.

Headline: A Monster of a Release
Abstract: A Monster Of a Releas
Lead_Paragraph: The date is Nov. 2, and if all the promotion has done its work, mall parking lots will be jumping with fans itching to storm any place that sells videos. Not a "Titanic"-size rush perhaps, but definitely a video event on the order of, say, one of the big Disney releases back in the days when consumers soaked up animated features by the tens of millions of cassettes.
Snippet: A Monster Of a Releas
Author: Peter

Headline: When It Helped to Be a Bit Nuts
Abstract: When It Helped To Be a Bit Nut
Lead_Paragraph: With all the dinosaurs, apes, robots, digital actors and artificial intelligence on screen, it's often hard to connect with anybody real. Not so during the Depression, when drama and the better screwball and romantic comedies had people to grab hold of.
Snippet: When It Helped To Be a Bit Nut

Headline: Rethinking Extras on DVD
Abstract: As DVD spreads, some video axioms are taking a bit of adjusting
Lead_Paragraph: As DVD spreads, some video axioms are taking a bit of adjusting. For example, in the disc's beginning it was generally held that the extra features on many DVD's would primarily interest only movie buffs. "The average Joe who buys at Wal- Mart — you wouldn't think they'd care," said Corie Tappin, senior vice president of marketing at MGM Home Entertainment. "But according to our research, even they are interested in some of them."
Snippet: As DVD spreads, some video axioms are taking a bit of adjusting
Author: Peter

Headline: George Lucas: A Galaxy of Myth, Money and Kids
Abstract: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Lead_Paragraph: SAN RAFAEL , Calif. — LIKE his films, which have brought vivid and elaborate fantasies to life in the multiplexes of America's most mundane shopping malls, George Lucas's elaborate film-set-like home is sequestered in a surprisingly everyday neighborhood here. Turn right by a supermarket parking lot, head up a hill past an assortment of lusterless middle-class homes -- an old washer and dryer are abandoned in the driveway of one -- and a visitor arrives at the electronically controlled gate that admits one to this private world. Inside, a huge 1860's Victorian house, remodeled and filled with the latest electronic gadgetry, perfectly expresses Mr. Lucas's retro-futurism.
Snippet: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Author: Orville Schell

Headline: Indiana Jones in Pursuit of Dad and the Grail
Abstract: font size="-1" (May 24, 1989) "The Last Crusade" aims to be a gigantic finale to the Indiana Jones trilogy. That's a lot of promise and hype to live up to.
Lead_Paragraph: Before Indiana Jones can team up with his father to elude the Nazis and race them to the Holy Grail, he must travel halfway around the world. He leaves the cozy American campus where he teaches archeology, guides a beautiful woman through a rat-infested tunnel in Venice and makes his way to a castle swarming with Nazis on the Austrian-German border. There, Indiana swashbuckles his way into the room where Henry Jones is held prisoner and finds his tweedy, academic, mildly befuddled Dad. ''Junior?'' asks Sean Connery, and Harrison Ford answers, with years of exasperation behind him, ''Don't call me that, please.''
Snippet: font size="-1" (May 24, 1989) "The Last Crusade" aims to be a gigantic finale to the Indiana Jones trilogy. That's a lot of promise and hype to live up to.
Author: Caryn James

Headline: 'Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom'
Abstract: font size="-1" (May 23, 1984) Watching "Indiana Jones" is like spending a day at an amusement park, which is probably what Steven Spielberg and his associates intended.
Lead_Paragraph: IF you've ever been a child or, barring that, if you've ever been around children, ages 7 to about 11, you may remember the sort of game in which each child attempts to come up with the vilest, most disgusting, most repulsive, most stomach-turning meal he can think of. It might consist of sheeps' eyes in runny aspic, live cockroaches wrapped in spider webs, juicy worms a la king and bats' brains with anchovies and chocolate sauce.
Snippet: font size="-1" (May 23, 1984) Watching "Indiana Jones" is like spending a day at an amusement park, which is probably what Steven Spielberg and his associates intended.
Author: Vincent Canby

Headline: Big Shrieks, Bigger Profits
Abstract: Disney won't discuss its projections for "Monsters, Inc.," but with any big Disney title it's always fun to conjecture how it will stack up against the studio's other major titles.
Lead_Paragraph: e just try to entertain ourselves," said Pete Docter, the director of "Monsters, Inc.," to be released on Tuesday by Disney. He and other filmmakers at Pixar Animation Studios, which created the film, start with things they were sure of in childhood. For example, they knew that toys come to life when left by themselves with no humans around, as in the two "Toy Story" movies.
Snippet: Disney won't discuss its projections for "Monsters, Inc.," but with any big Disney title it's always fun to conjecture how it will stack up against the studio's other major titles.
Author: Peter

Headline: An Olympics Ever So Human
Abstract: "Tokyo Olympiad," Kon Ichikawa's 170-minutes documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, is one of the most enthralling films about sport ever made.
Lead_Paragraph: When Kon Ichikawa was asked to make a documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, the Japanese authorities from the emperor on down expected his cameras to stick to business on the track or in the pool and not go wandering off at every little distraction. Yet no sooner does Billy Mills of the United States win the 10,000-meter run than Mr. Ichikawa moves off into the crowd for a close look at the wattles of 60-something men.
Snippet: "Tokyo Olympiad," Kon Ichikawa's 170-minutes documentary of the 1964 Olympic Games in Tokyo, is one of the most enthralling films about sport ever made.
Author: Peter

Headline: From the BBC, a Watery World
Abstract: "The Blue Planet," an eight-hour, four-part BBC production about life in the oceans, was released last week on cassette and DVD.
Lead_Paragraph: Across the water is the leviathan called the BBC: a gargantuan producer of all kinds of programming, with five channels and a 24-hour-a-day public. In the water, a blue whale, 100 feet long and with arteries big enough for a man to swim through, cruises azure seas as part of "The Blue Planet," an eight-hour, four-part BBC production about life in the oceans.
Snippet: "The Blue Planet," an eight-hour, four-part BBC production about life in the oceans, was released last week on cassette and DVD.
Author: Peter

Headline: George Lucas: A Galaxy of Myth, Money and Kids
Abstract: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Lead_Paragraph: SAN RAFAEL , Calif. — LIKE his films, which have brought vivid and elaborate fantasies to life in the multiplexes of America's most mundane shopping malls, George Lucas's elaborate film-set-like home is sequestered in a surprisingly everyday neighborhood here. Turn right by a supermarket parking lot, head up a hill past an assortment of lusterless middle-class homes -- an old washer and dryer are abandoned in the driveway of one -- and a visitor arrives at the electronically controlled gate that admits one to this private world. Inside, a huge 1860's Victorian house, remodeled and filled with the latest electronic gadgetry, perfectly expresses Mr. Lucas's retro-futurism.
Snippet: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Author: Orville Schell

Headline: 'Fahrenheit 9/11' Wins Top Prize at Cannes
Abstract: "Fahrenheit 9/11," Michael Moore's critique of the Bush administration's foreign policies, won the Palme d'Or at Cannes.

Headline: A Tale Explained as Well as Told
Abstract: Extra features are at battalion strength on a three-disc DVD special edition of Ridley Scott's "Black Hawk Down."
Lead_Paragraph: Like a wave of the title helicopters, "Black Hawk Down" has landed this week in a three-disc DVD special edition ($39.95) from Columbia TriStar. Extra features are at battalion strength for Ridley Scott's film about the ambush of American troops in Mogadishu, Somalia, in October 1993. Mr. Scott and many others contribute to three separate audio commentaries. A documentary about the making of the film runs 150 minutes, seven minutes longer than the movie. Two documentaries, from the History Channel and the PBS "Frontline" series, examine the real battle of Mogadishu.
Snippet: Extra features are at battalion strength on a three-disc DVD special edition of Ridley Scott's "Black Hawk Down."
Author: Peter

Headline: Dogme: Still Strong, but Less Dogmatic
Abstract: It has now been nine years since the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier gave birth to Dogme95, and the movement he began is still going strong.
Lead_Paragraph: ON March 20, 1995, the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier stood up at a conference in Paris on the 100th anniversary of the cinema and tossed handfuls of bright red pamphlets into the audience. "It seems to me that for the last 10 years film has been rubbish," Mr. von Trier proclaimed. "So my question was, what can we do about this?" His answer was Dogme95, a new film movement, born half in facetiousness and half in seriousness, whose rules were spelled out in the flyers as "The Vow of Chastity."
Snippet: It has now been nine years since the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier gave birth to Dogme95, and the movement he began is still going strong.
Author: Dave Kehr

Headline: Human Drama Unfolds the World Over
Abstract: Reviews of "Greeneland: Graham Greene and the Cinema," "The Squid and the Whale," "I Am" and "Something Like Happiness."
Lead_Paragraph: The 43rd New York Film Festival continues with Noah Baumbach's latest, "The Squid and the Whale," one of the highlights of this year's Sundance Film Festival, and selections from the Czech Republic ("Something Like Happiness") and from Poland ("I Am"). Also on tap is "Greeneland: Graham Greene and the Cinema," an illustrated lecture about the British novelist's long and fascinating affair with the seventh art. ("What I object to," wrote Greene, "is the idea that it is the critic's business to assist films to fulfill a social function. The critic's business should be confined to the art.") In addition, look for a reprise of Steven Soderbergh's latest, "Bubble," and two screenings of "Capote," Bennett Miller's already justly lauded film starring Philip Seymour Hoffman as Truman Capote. A full review of that film will appear in The Times tomorrow. Essential viewing can be found in the festival's sidebar program "The Beauty of the Everyday: Japan's Shochiku Company at 110," dedicated to the great Japanese film studio. Among the treasures on view are early films from the auteurs Heinosuke Gosho, Yasujiro Shimazu, Hiroshi Shimizu Yasujiro Ozu, Mikio Naruse and Kenji Mizoguchi. You can see more details about this valuable series online at www.filmlinc.com/wrt/showing/shochiku.htm. MANOHLA DARGIS
Snippet: Reviews of "Greeneland: Graham Greene and the Cinema," "The Squid and the Whale," "I Am" and "Something Like Happiness."

Abstract: The rebellious prodigy, who electrified a generation and forever transformed the art of screen acting, died in Los Angeles.

Headline: Dogme: Still Strong, but Less Dogmatic
Abstract: It has now been nine years since the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier gave birth to Dogme95, and the movement he began is still going strong.
Lead_Paragraph: ON March 20, 1995, the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier stood up at a conference in Paris on the 100th anniversary of the cinema and tossed handfuls of bright red pamphlets into the audience. "It seems to me that for the last 10 years film has been rubbish," Mr. von Trier proclaimed. "So my question was, what can we do about this?" His answer was Dogme95, a new film movement, born half in facetiousness and half in seriousness, whose rules were spelled out in the flyers as "The Vow of Chastity."
Snippet: It has now been nine years since the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier gave birth to Dogme95, and the movement he began is still going strong.
Author: Dave Kehr

Headline: Experiences of a New Director
Abstract: With its room for interviews and other opportunities for documentation, DVD can be especially good at catching fresh filmmaking experiences, particularly by first-time directors.
Lead_Paragraph: With its room for interviews and other opportunities for documentation, DVD can be especially good at catching fresh filmmaking experiences, particularly by first-time directors. "Never let them see you sweat," John Singleton says on a two-disc special edition of "Boyz N the Hood" (1991) released this week by Columbia TriStar. He was four months out of film school at the University of Southern California, and Columbia Pictures had given him $6 million to make a movie shot in the ghetto. Every day he showed up early to learn what everybody was doing.
Snippet: With its room for interviews and other opportunities for documentation, DVD can be especially good at catching fresh filmmaking experiences, particularly by first-time directors.
Author: Peter

Headline: An Insider's Life in Hollywood
Abstract: Robert Evans, the former head of Paramount Pictures, tells his story in the documentary "The Kid Stays in the Picture."
Lead_Paragraph: 'm pulling Mia," said Frank Sinatra. In the late 1960's Robert Evans was head of Paramount and supervising movies like "Barefoot in the Park," "The Odd Couple" and "Rosemary's Baby," directed by Roman Polanski. As Mr. Evans tells the story in the documentary "The Kid Stays in the Picture," released this week on DVD and VHS by Warner, Mr. Polanski worked slowly enough to agitate Gulf & Western Industries, which then owned Paramount.
Snippet: Robert Evans, the former head of Paramount Pictures, tells his story in the documentary "The Kid Stays in the Picture."

Abstract: With documentaries about the making of movies so common on DVD these days, it's interesting to come across one, for "Lost in La Mancha," which tells how the movie wasn't made.
Lead_Paragraph: With documentaries about the making of movies so common on DVD these days, it's interesting to come across one that tells how a movie wasn't made. "Fell through" is too mild a term for the filmmaking fiasco chronicled in "Lost in La Mancha," to be released next week by Docurama.
Snippet: With documentaries about the making of movies so common on DVD these days, it's interesting to come across one, for "Lost in La Mancha," which tells how the movie wasn't made.

Headline: A Tale Explained as Well as Told
Abstract: Extra features are at battalion strength on a three-disc DVD special edition of Ridley Scott's "Black Hawk Down."
Lead_Paragraph: Like a wave of the title helicopters, "Black Hawk Down" has landed this week in a three-disc DVD special edition ($39.95) from Columbia TriStar. Extra features are at battalion strength for Ridley Scott's film about the ambush of American troops in Mogadishu, Somalia, in October 1993. Mr. Scott and many others contribute to three separate audio commentaries. A documentary about the making of the film runs 150 minutes, seven minutes longer than the movie. Two documentaries, from the History Channel and the PBS "Frontline" series, examine the real battle of Mogadishu.
Snippet: Extra features are at battalion strength on a three-disc DVD special edition of Ridley Scott's "Black Hawk Down."
Author: Peter

Headline: 'Perdition,' With Its Ghosts
Abstract: A fine DVD released this week shows the real strengths of "Road to Perdition" are in the film's art direction, cinematography, sound, sound editing and original score.
Lead_Paragraph: Among the early front-runners for major Oscar nominations, Sam Mendes's "Road to Perdition" was passed in the home stretch by the likes of "The Pianist" and "Gangs of New York." In 1999 Mr. Mendes's first feature film, "American Beauty," won in the best film, director and actor categories, but this time the only "Perdition" contender for the so-called big six Oscars is Paul Newman as best supporting actor for his portayal of the mob boss John Rooney.

O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. As for "The Mystery of Picasso" (1956), the director Henri-Georges Clouzot died in 1977, but he has plenty of good current representation to help explain his thinking on a DVD available from Milestone (distributed by Image).
Snippet: DVD as agent for one's work serves figures as diverse as Steven Soderbergh and Pablo Picasso in two new releases.

Headline: Old Films Meet New Technology
Abstract: Paramount took extra measures with its very fine-looking special editions of William Wyler's "Roman Holiday" (1953) and Billy Wilder's "Sunset Boulevard" (1950).
Lead_Paragraph: DVD can be unforgiving with older films. "It's such a lossless medium," said Phil Murphy, senior vice president for operations for Paramount television. By lossless he refers to visual glitches on much-used prints that are hard if not impossible to avoid on disc. On videotape there is a kind of settling into visual mediocrity that results in a loss of the bad along with the good, a kind of softening of imperfections. Only so much can be expected from VHS in the first place.
Snippet: Paramount took extra measures with its very fine-looking special editions of William Wyler's "Roman Holiday" (1953) and Billy Wilder's "Sunset Boulevard" (1950).
Author: Peter

Headline: 'In the Bedroom' Without Frills
Abstract: There isn't an extra feature to be found on the DVD release of Todd Field's "In the Bedroom."
Lead_Paragraph: With all the attention "In the Bedroom" had in theaters, not to mention its five Oscar nominations, its director, Todd Field, could be excused for some soul-baring in the form of a director's commentary or the like on the DVD, to be released Tuesday by Buena Vista. Instead there isn't an extra feature to be found — another smart move for a small, quiet film that tells its exceedingly powerful story in rich detail but totally without excess.

Headline: A Spiritual Trek for Salt in Tibet
Abstract: On July 23, Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary "The Saltmen of Tibet" on cassette and DVD.
Lead_Paragraph: Nothing beats a good trek movie. On Tuesday Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary "The Saltmen of Tibet" on cassette and DVD. At the outset a song tells us that we are in the Kingdom of Ling, at the center of the world, a blue-turquoise place. Nomads are preparing to drive 160 yaks on a monthlong pilgrimage to Lake Tsentso to collect salt to trade for grain.
Snippet: On July 23, Zeitgeist is to release Ulrike Koch's documentary "The Saltmen of Tibet" on cassette and DVD.
Author: Peter

Headline: DVD Has Begun to Take Over
Abstract: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format.
Lead_Paragraph: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format. Last week Circuit City, the large electronics retailer, said it planned to drop videocassettes altogether in favor of the disc. Of the more than 10 million copies of "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" sold since its release by Warner on May 28, almost 60 percent were DVD's.
Snippet: Introduced five years ago, DVD has moved from catching on to taking over. The process is gradual, but everywhere VHS is passing the torch to the new format.
Author: Peter

Headline: Ready to Play a Mind Game?
Abstract: Don't bother poking the menu key on a new DVD edition of Christopher Nolan's "Memento." Neither of the two discs has a menu, or one that lists features in standard fashion.
Lead_Paragraph: Don't bother poking the menu key on a new DVD edition of Christopher Nolan's "Memento," released this week by Columbia TriStar. Neither of the two discs has a menu, or one that lists features in standard fashion. Instead, one gets to the contents through a "mental health battery," or series of questions and exercises to measure contextual retention, comprehension skills and the like. Respond the right way, and you will find the feature you seek. Answer another way, and you won't.
Snippet: Don't bother poking the menu key on a new DVD edition of Christopher Nolan's "Memento." Neither of the two discs has a menu, or one that lists features in standard fashion.

Headline: How Spidey Was Hatched
Abstract: "Spider-Man: The Ultimate Villain Showdown," released this week on DVD and videocassette, contains several episodes from the old animated TV series and remarks from Stan Lee, the creator of Spider-Man.
Lead_Paragraph: As Spider-Man in Sam Raimi's film, which opens today (review, Weekend Page 1), the vegetarian Tobey Maguire may not fit a steak eater's notion of a superhero, but he seems to come close to what Stan Lee had in mind when he and the artist Steve Ditko rolled out that Marvel Comics action figure in 1962. On a couple of new DVD's, Mr. Lee says he wanted the average person to identify with Spider-Man, a k a Peter Parker, which meant giving him more feelings and saddling him with worries about girls, family and friends.

Headline: Japan's Artistry, New and Classic
Abstract: This month brings the release on DVD and videocassette of Rintaro's stunning animated film "Metropolis" (2001) and a DVD special edition of Akira Kurosawa's "Rashomon" (1950).
Lead_Paragraph: It's a busy time for Japanese titles. Next week Columbia TriStar will release "Metropolis," Rintaro's stunning animated film based on a manga (comic book) of Osamu Tezuka, on videocassette and DVD. "The effect of almost two hours of exquisitely detailed and remarkably varied cityscapes, rendered in a palette of colors and light effects that would make a live-action cinematographer or an Italian Renaissance painter weep, is exhausting and exhilarating," A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times when the film opened in theaters in January.

Headline: Making Room for DVD and VHS
Abstract: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies
Lead_Paragraph: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies. In short, there isn't money or shelf space for everything. More obscure titles that were once distributed routinely, if not profusely, on videocassette are being dropped by studios more interested in developing the biggest and best known older films in DVD special editions that will sell by the bushel at mass outlets like Best Buy and Wal- Mart.
Snippet: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies

Headline: Filming the Comic and the Absurd in Czech History
Abstract: Using a filmmaker's wizardry, Jan Hrebejk is resurrecting memories buried by the enforced forgetting of the Soviet years, filming the stories of a nation finally able to reclaim its history
Lead_Paragraph: PRAGUE — Try as he might, Jan Hrebejk could never conjure up the time machine that he had longed for as a child, but decades later he has found a better way to bend time to his will. Using a filmmaker's wizardry, he is resurrecting memories buried by the enforced forgetting of the Soviet years, filming the stories of a nation finally able to reclaim its history.

Headline: George Lucas: A Galaxy of Myth, Money and Kids
Abstract: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Lead_Paragraph: SAN RAFAEL , Calif. — LIKE his films, which have brought vivid and elaborate fantasies to life in the multiplexes of America's most mundane shopping malls, George Lucas's elaborate film-set-like home is sequestered in a surprisingly everyday neighborhood here. Turn right by a supermarket parking lot, head up a hill past an assortment of lusterless middle-class homes -- an old washer and dryer are abandoned in the driveway of one -- and a visitor arrives at the electronically controlled gate that admits one to this private world. Inside, a huge 1860's Victorian house, remodeled and filled with the latest electronic gadgetry, perfectly expresses Mr. Lucas's retro-futurism.
Snippet: font size="-1" (March 21, 1999) It was a fascination with children and his penchant for looking at the world as if he were still a child himself that led George Lucas off on his whole "Star Wars" odyssey.
Author: Orville Schell

Headline: Imagining the Holocaust to Remember It
Abstract: font size="-1" (December 15, 1993) "Schindler's List," directed with fury and immediacy by a profoundly surprising Steven Spielberg, presents the Holocaust as if discovering it anew.
Lead_Paragraph: There is a real photographic record of some of the people and places depicted in "Schindler's List," and it has a haunting history. Raimund Titsch, an Austrian Catholic who managed a uniform factory within the Plaszow labor camp in Poland, surreptitiously took pictures of what he saw. Fearful of having the pictures developed, he hid his film in a steel box, which he buried in a park outside Vienna and then did not disturb for nearly 20 years. Although it was sold secretly by Titsch when he was terminally ill, the film remained undeveloped until after his death.
Snippet: font size="-1" (December 15, 1993) "Schindler's List," directed with fury and immediacy by a profoundly surprising Steven Spielberg, presents the Holocaust as if discovering it anew.

Headline: Indiana Jones in Pursuit of Dad and the Grail
Abstract: font size="-1" (May 24, 1989) "The Last Crusade" aims to be a gigantic finale to the Indiana Jones trilogy. That's a lot of promise and hype to live up to.
Lead_Paragraph: Before Indiana Jones can team up with his father to elude the Nazis and race them to the Holy Grail, he must travel halfway around the world. He leaves the cozy American campus where he teaches archeology, guides a beautiful woman through a rat-infested tunnel in Venice and makes his way to a castle swarming with Nazis on the Austrian-German border. There, Indiana swashbuckles his way into the room where Henry Jones is held prisoner and finds his tweedy, academic, mildly befuddled Dad. ''Junior?'' asks Sean Connery, and Harrison Ford answers, with years of exasperation behind him, ''Don't call me that, please.''
Snippet: font size="-1" (May 24, 1989) "The Last Crusade" aims to be a gigantic finale to the Indiana Jones trilogy. That's a lot of promise and hype to live up to.
Author: Caryn James

Headline: From a Palette of Clichés Comes 'The Color Purple'
Abstract: ''The Color Purple'' is lavender. That's according to Steven Spielberg, the director of the screen adaptation of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel. The letters that spell out the film's opening credits are lavender -the shade that dying violets take on just before they turn crumbly and gray. The flowers that bloom throughout the film also are lavender, not purple. It may be that lavender& The movie is faithful to the events of the novel, but it sees those events through lavender-colored glasses that transform them into fiction of an entirely different order. It's also a kind of fiction that, I suspect, would have been enthusiastically endorsed by an old-time Hollywood mogul like Louis B. Mayer, who didn't believe it was Hollywood's job to depress its customers by reflecting life's bleaker truths.
